description: From Middle French obliquité, from Latin obliquitas, from obliquus (“oblique”). Corresponding to oblique +‎ -ity.

entries.meaning: The quality of being oblique in direction, deviating from the horizontal or vertical; or the angle created by such a deviation. [from 15th c.]
(astronomy, by extension, of a planet) Axial tilt.
Mental or moral deviation or perversity; immorality. [from 15th c.]
The quality of being obscure, oftentimes willfully, sometimes as an exercise in euphemism. [from 17th c.]
